titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Rocko Michael Fasanella Collection
titlestmt.author: Preliminary inventory by Carol King

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:53

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection consists of material relating to Dr. Leon Stansfield Stone and his work on lens regeneration in salamanders. Also included are papers documenting the professional career of Dr. Rocko Fasanella, specifically the Fasanella-Servat operation for ptosis.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rocko Michael Fasanella Collection (MS 1596). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Dr. Rocko M. Fasanella, 1990-1997. Gift of Dr. Edmund S. Crelin, 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rocko M. Fasanella Collection, which dates from 1921-1991, consists of correspondence, printed material, slides, and a videocassette which document the Fasanella-Servat surgical procedure for minimal ptosis. This operation was developed by Rocko M. Fasanella and Javier Servat in 1961. Related items consist of printed material pertaining to ophthalmic surgery and biographical information on Rocko M. Fasanella, Javier Servat, and other renowned ophthalmologists.

Dr. Leon Stansfield Stone is also highlighted in this collection, with reprints, writings, films, slides, and other printed material documenting his experiments on the regeneration of the eye of an amblystoma, a salamander-like animal. In recognition of this work, Dr. Stone received the Doyne Award from Oxford in 1940 and his discoveries form the basis of modern research into the regeneration of traumatized nerves.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Rocko Michael Fasanella was born in Trenton, New Jersey in 1916. He received his bachelor's degree from Yale in 1939, and his medical degree in 1943. Fasanella was an intern (1943-1944), an assistant resident and resident in ophthalmology (1948-1950), and chief of ophthalmology (1951-1961) at Grace-New Haven Hospital in New Haven, Connecticut. He was also an instructor (1950-1951) and associate clinical professor of ophthalmology and visual science (1961-) at the Yale Medical School. Fasanella has pioneered many innovations in his field and has been active in humanitarian causes around the world. Fasanella died at his home in Orange, Connecticut, on February 11, 2009.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by accession.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.
